publicwhip.spmotion: *S3M-8060 Willie Coffey: The King’s Speech and Speech and Language Therapy—That the Parliament welcomes the success of the film, The King’s Speech, which tells the story of King George VI’s battle to overcome a stammer, at a variety of awards ceremonies, most recently receiving four Oscars, including for best film and best original screenplay; notes that the writer, David Seidler, was motivated to write the story of the king’s treatment after himself overcoming at 16 a stammer that had developed when he was two years old; further notes that the king’s therapist, Lionel Logue, was recommended to the royal family by the Scottish publisher, John Murray, after Mr Logue had successfully treated his nephew, and acknowledges the support given by those concerned with the film to the work of the Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists through highlighting the importance of speech and language services, which, according to independent research, generate £6.43 in increased lifetime earnings for every £1 invested in such therapies.
